author: JOHN CONROY
title: Aussie stock market in the red despite boost for energy stocks
text:
THE Australian share market has taken a late-day tumble, closing down more than 2 per cent with $30 billion stripped from its value.
After a late selloff, the benchmark ASX 200 index closed down 2.1 per cent today in its biggest slide since last Monday’s 4.1 per cent plunge.
Over the past two days, the market has shed 3.2 per cent, losing about $47 billion in value.
The slide today came despite strong gains in the oil price overnight — a development buoying energy stocks in early trade today.
Oil prices chalked up a third straight session of gains above 5 per cent overnight with US Nymex crude surging 8.8 per cent to $US49.20 while global benchmark Brent crude jumped 8.2 per cent to $US54.15.
IG chief market strategist Chris Weston said energy stocks' outperformance in early trading was not enough to boost the broader market.
Energy stocks opened 2.62 per cent higher overall, with Santos 3.31 per cent stronger to $5.30 and Woodside Petroleum up 2.6 per cent to $33.10. Oil Search had lifted 3.53 per cent to $7.04.
But they all lost ground as trading continued, following the release of weak manufaturing figures in China — Australia’s biggest trading partner — and closed in the red.
Santos was hit heavily, closing 6.6 per cent lower at $4.79. Woodside shares closed 2 per cent lower at $31.62 and Oil Search ended down 0.9 per cent at $6.74.
The banks again fell heavily, with ANZ down 3.1 per cent and Westpac off 2.9 per cent. AMP tumbled 4.9 per cent.
